meanings.definition: To release from slavery or servitude.
meanings.sent1: The kind owner decided to manumit the enslaved people on his plantation.
meanings.sent2: The abolitionist fought to manumit all those who were held in chains.
meanings.sent3: The wizard used a magical spell to manumit the captured creatures from the evil sorcerer's control.
meanings.sent4: Her powerful speech aimed to manumit the minds of the oppressed from the chains of ignorance.
meanings.sent5: The sun's rays seemed to manumit the flowers from the darkness of the night.

meanings.sent1: The hero's brave actions helped manumit the hostages from the villain's grasp.
meanings.sent2: The key to the cage would manumit the bird back into the wild.
meanings.sent3: The magical sword had the power to manumit the cursed prince from his eternal slumber.
meanings.sent4: Her soothing words seemed to manumit the tension in the room.
meanings.sent5: The artist's brushstrokes appeared to manumit the colors onto the canvas.

meanings.definition: To grant freedom to a slave.
meanings.sent1: The decree from the king would manumit the loyal servant from his chains.
meanings.sent2: The document signed by the master would manumit the enslaved individual.
meanings.sent3: The fairy godmother used her magic wand to manumit Cinderella from her stepmother's control.
meanings.sent4: The melody of the song seemed to manumit the singer's emotions.
meanings.sent5: The gentle touch of the healer appeared to manumit the pain from the patient's body.
